repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Additional Financing for the
            Second Health Systems Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Additional Financing for
            the Second Health Systems Development Project for Nigeria
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory;
            risk to development outcome was high; Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            first, to adequately address the potential trade-off between
            a project's technical scope and its geographical reach,
            project design must be both simple and adaptable to changes
            in both the policy and political environments. Second, while
            a previous health Implementation Completion Report (ICR)
            concluded that it was essential to focus on results, another
            was somewhat more nuanced arguing that a supply approach
            needs strong capacity to strategically administer, combine
            and utilize inputs to achieve results. Third, rigorous
            national-level monitoring and evaluation measures with
            accountability at state and local levels are crucial for
            project success. Finally, technical staff of the state
            ministry of health and the state ministry of local
            government should participate in project preparation to
            engage and sustain commitment for project ownership and coordination.

13971359.theme: Tuberculosis,Population and reproductive health,Health system performance,Child health,Participation and civic engagement

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Second Health Systems Development
            Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper provides additional
            financing to the Federal Republic of Nigeria, Second Health
            Systems Development Project (HSDP II). The Bank has been
            supporting the thirty-six states of the Nigerian Federation
            through the HSDP II in improving the maternal and child
            health (MCH) status in Nigeria, which is amongst the poorest
            in Sub Saharan Africa. The additional credit will help
            finance the costs that accrued after the project was
            restructured in 2005 and implementation was accelerated and
            effectively scaled up. Of the total proposed supplement is
            allocated to 22 States and the Federal Ministry of Health,
            that were selected based on their performance to date, and
            will support the completion of original project activities
            that had already been approved in work plans for the
            improved delivery of primary health care services. The 22
            states expected to participate in the first instance are:
            Akwa Ibom, Abia, Anambra, Bauchi, Benue, Borno, Ekiti,
            Enugu, Gombe, Imo, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kogi, Kano, Kwara,
            Nasarawa, Ondo, Osun, Plateau, Sokoto Taraba and the FCT.
            The additional credit will specifically support four sets of
            activities within the broader context of strengthening
            primary health care services, namely: (a) rehabilitation and
            refurbishment of schools of health technology and schools of
            nursing and midwifery, with the twin objectives of
            augmenting the numbers of qualified health care personnel
            and of having these schools secure relevant accreditation;
            (b) support services, including the refurbishment and
            equipping of primary health facilities at the community
            level, training of health service workers, procurement of
            drugs and other medical supplies; (c) immunization
            activities, such as the procurement and repair of the cold
            chain equipment and training of vaccinators; and (d)
            strengthening of monitoring and evaluation (M&E) systems
            and processes at both the State and Federal levels.

repnme.cdata!: Nigeria - Second Health Systems Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Health Systems Development
            Project aims to assist the Nigerian authorities in
            redressing the deteriorated delivery of basic health care
            services, and, to build institutional capacities that would
            pave the way for a sustained development of the
            country's health care system. Through its components,
            the project will: 1) support all states in strengthening the
            capacity of the State Ministry of Health in the areas of
            planning, financial management, and monitoring and
            evaluation, while a limited support will be provided to
            improve the technical skills of trainers, and key health
            providers. Support activities will cover managerial
            processes and skills; technical skill development; improved
            health management information systems, and, access to
            information and communication technology, in addition to
            research and studies; 2) finance, and support activities
            that improve the delivery of primary health care services,
            emphasizing on strengthening immunization services, safe
            motherhood interventions, and communicable disease control
            (both endemic and epidemic diseases). Access to health care
            will be improved, as will the availability of essential, and
            generic drugs in health facilities, in addition to quality
            of training in nursing, mid-wife services, and health
            technology schools; and, 3) support capacity building, and
            strengthening of public health functions, and processes at
            the Federal Ministry of Health, and, coordinate, monitor and
            evaluate the implementation of the project. Support for the
            formulation of health policy, and strategies, the health
            reform process, and for strengthened management information
            systems will be financed.
